body: Legal executions in California were authorized under the Criminal Practices Act of 1851.
title: Legal executions in California authorized
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
The state legislature adds the "death penalty" to section 124 of the state penal code, spelling out the requirements for an execution to take place. Such as:
Where:
Must within the walls or yard of a jail, or some convenient private place in the county.
Who must be present:
The Sheriff of the county, a physician, the District Attorney of the county, and at least twelve reputable citizens selected by the Sheriff.
Who shall be present at request of the defendant:
Ministers of the gospel (not to exceed two) and any persons, relatives or friends (not to exceed five).
Who can't be present:
No other persons than those mentioned in this section can be present at the execution, nor can any person under age be allowed to witness the same.
title: Capital punishment incorporated into California Penal Code
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: California law is amended allowing for executions to take place inside one of the state prisons - San Quentin or Folsom. The process will be executed by the warden instead of the Sheriff.
title: Amendment: capital punishment occur inside state prisons
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Jose Gabriel, convicted of murdering an aged farm couple, was hanged at San Quentin.
title: First state-conducted execution at San Quentin
caption: Convicts in the exercise yard of San Quentin State Prison in California. (Photo by Harry Benson/Express/Getty Images)
readmoresource: Death Penalty Focus

title: First execution at Folsom
caption: Folsom State Prison in 1898 (Source: Popular Science Monthly Volume 54)
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: The decision did not affect the execution method for those already sentenced.
title: Lethal gas replaces hanging
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: A total of 92 were hanged at Folsom. Since only San Quentin has installed the gas chamber in 1938, all executions now take place at San Quentin.
title: Last execution by hanging at Folsom
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: A total of 215 inmates were hanged at San Quentin.
title: Last execution by hanging at San Quentin
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
Robert L. Cannon, 30, and Albert Kessell, 29, died in the chamber on Dec. 2, 1938. They had been convicted of murdering Folsom Penitentiary Warden Clarence Larkin in a foiled escape attempt.

From 1938 through 1967 a total of 194 persons were executed by gas, all at San Quentin. This total includes four women.
title: First execution by lethal gas
readmoresource: L.A. Times

body: A landmark case in which the California Supreme Court declares the death penalty cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the state constitution. As a result, 107 inmates are taken off death row and resentenced.
title: People v. Anderson case

body:
California electorate overruled the State Supreme Court's decision by a state constitutional amendment. Proposition 17 added Article 1, Section 27 to the state constitution, which reads:

"All statutes of this state in effect on February 17, 1972, requiring, authorizing, imposing, or relating to the death penalty are in full force and effect, subject to legislative amendment or repeal by statute, initiative, or referendum."
title: Proposition 17 overruled court decision
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Furman v. Georgia decision in 1972 ruled on the requirement for a degree of consistency in the application of the death penalty. The case led to a de facto moratorium on capital punishment throughout the United States.
title: U.S. Supreme Court held death penalty unconstitutional

body:
Circumstances where death penalty is mandatory:
Kidnapping if the victim dies, train wrecking if any person dies, assault by a life prisoner if the victim dies within a year, treason against the state, and first-degree murder under specific conditions.
title: Death penalty made mandatory in certain cases
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
The California Supreme Court, basing its decision on a United States Supreme Court ruling earlier that year, held that the California death penalty statute was unconstitutional under the Federal Constitution because it did not allow the defendant to present any evidence in mitigation.

Following this ruling, 70 inmates had their sentences changed to other than death.
title: State Supreme Court held death penalty unconstitutional for 2nd time
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
Under the new statute, evidence in mitigation is permitted. The Penal Code was also revised to include the sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Below are some circumstances for different possible punishments.

Punishable by death penalty:
First-degree murder for financial gain, murder by a person previously convicted of murder, murder of multiple victims, murder with torture, murder of a peace officer, murder of a witness to prevent testimony and several other murders under particular circumstances.
Punishable by life imprisonment without parole:
Kidnapping for ransom, extortion, or robbery.
Punishable by either death or life imprisonment without parole:
Treason, train derailing or wrecking, and securing the death of an innocent person through perjury.
title: Legislature re-enacted death penalty
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
California Proposition 7, or the Death Penalty Act, was on the November 7, 1978 statewide ballot in California as an initiated state statute, where it was approved. It remains the death penalty statute under which California currently operates.

What did Proposition 7 change:
Increased the penalties for first and second degree murder;
Expanded the list of special circumstances requiring a sentence of either death or life imprisonment without the possibility of parole;
Revised existing law relating to mitigating or aggravating circumstances.

Although the death penalty was reinstated in 1978, no executions were carried out in California until April 1992.
title: Proposition 7 superseded the 1977 statutes
readmoresource: Ballotpedia

body: Robert Alton Harris, convicted of killing two teenagers in San Diego, executed by lethal gas - the first California execution in 25 years since the 1978 statute.
title: Robert Alton Harris put to death in San Quentin
caption: NCCC Garbage Disposal: The Execution of Robert Alton Harris in the California Gas Chamber
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Lethal injection was added as a method of execution. Inmates may choose between injection and lethal gas.
title: Lethal injection added as method of execution
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: The Judge from Northern District (San Francisco) ruled that the gas chamber was cruel and unusual punishment.
title: U.S. District Judge barred lethal gas
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Lethal injection became default method of execution.
title: Ruling upheld by the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
caption: Former gas chamber converted to lethal injection chamber. (Source: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation)
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Serial killer William George Bonin, convicted of sexually assaulting and killing 14 boys in Los Angeles and Orange Counties, was the first California inmate executed by lethal injection.
title: Serial killer William Bonin executed by lethal injection
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Michael Angelo Morales’ execution was stayed because of his claim that California’s administration of its lethal injection protocol violated the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment.
title: Morales’ execution stayed for violation of Eighth Amendment
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
“California’s lethal-injection protocol – as actually administered in practice – create[d] an undue and unnecessary risk that an inmate will suffer pain so extreme that it offends the Eight Amendment.”
- U.S. District Court.

Five deficiencies identified by the Court about lethal injection protocol:
Inconsistent and unreliable screening of execution team members;
A lack of meaningful training, supervision, and oversight of the execution team;
Inconsistent and unreliable record keeping;
Improper mixing, preparation, and administration of sodium thiopental by the execution team;
Inadequate lighting, overcrowded conditions, and poorly designed facilities in which the execution team must work.
title: U.S. District Court held lethal injection unconstitutional
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: The Governor directed the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) to undertake a thorough review of all aspects of its lethal injection protocols.
title: Review of lethal injection protocols
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
In the report, in order to address the Court’s concerns and improve the lethal injection protocol, the State:

Established a screening process for selection of execution team members and a periodic review process for team members;
Established a comprehensive training program for all execution team members;
Developed standardized record keeping to ensure there are complete and reliable records of each execution;
Developed training processes for the proper use of sodium thiopental;
Recommended improvements to the lethal injection facility at San Quentin State Prison, including steps to ensure adequate equipment, lighting and space;
Proposed revisions to the lethal injection protocol, including modifying the procedures used to administer the lethal injection.
title: CDCR proposed revisions to lethal injection protocol
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body: Regulations governing the use of lethal injection take effect.
title: Regulations for use of lethal injection take effect
readmoresource: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

body:
Proposition 34 would have replaced the death penalty with life imprisonment. It was narrowly defeated with 52 percent of the vote against and 48 percent for.

At the time of the vote on Proposition 34, California had 725 people on death row. If Proposition 34 had been approved, their sentences would have been replaced with "life in prison without the possibility of parole."
title: Proposition 34 defeated on ballot
readmoresource: Ballotpedia

body: The Santa Ana-based Judge Cormac J. Carney said the system is so broken that it unfairly leaves inmates with uncertain fates -- often for decades. In California, there are 748 people on death row, the most of any state.
title: Federal judge rules California death penalty unconstitutional
readmoresource: CNN
